Sir, Lord, with reference to my circular despatch S.L T o.33 of the 10th September 1937, and to my despatch o ,-l 57 61 oi today f s date, 1 have the honour to state that, on the occasion of the renewal for a further year from the llth February 1938, of the Muscat Sommercial Treaty of 1891, the Spltan expressed his unwillingness to agree to any further renewal after the llth February 1938. advantage was accordingly taken of his highness's recent visit to this country to discuss with him informally the terms of a new treaty to take its place. ~ copy is enclosed of the draft treaty which has now been sent to His hi^iness as a result of the discussions, xhis iraft is subject to further consideration on both sides, but, subject to this, it is hoped that the n negotiations may be resumed with his highie ss in July after his return to muscat and that they will be concluded in time for the new treaty to be signed there during that month. I have, etc., 3d. LULJOLL , aJ JOLaU.•j & ^ P.Z.7uo6/36 A Enclosure in Doniinions OfEice covering note dated 14-th October ? 1930. D0*.iluIOi o ICE, S.7.1. 14th October, 19.C. My dear Hijh Corrrdssioner, The questions dealt with in your letter of. the 16th August to the Secret air’ of State regarding- the draft Treat' r betv/een the Uniced i-ingdOiU and i .u sc at have been carefull’’ consiaei ed oy tiie conioetent Denartments of Lis Ha.lesty 1 s Government in the United Kingdom, and I am now in a position to co.nmunicate to you the viev/s of Lis 1.1 a jesty ? s Government on the points raised. Tne Articles of the draft Treaty to which His Majesty';: Government in the Union have called attention fall into two categories, namely, Articles 1, 20 a.nd 21, which are general provisions of a type which it has been customary for many years past to include in general Commercial Treaties negotiated on behalf of the United Kingdom, and Articles 1 , 14 and 15 which i elate to ti*e securing of special extra-territorial rights in the territories of the Sultan of Muscat, and it will be convenient to deal separately with these two categories. As stated aoove, tne Articles in the first category follow existing practice in regard to the draft ng of Commercial Treaties. ihis practice is based on the recorumendat. ons contained in a Keport of the Drafting Committee of the Inter- Imperial Delations Coriimittee of the Imperial Conference of 1930 whicn were accepted by the representatives of the Governments then pj.ese.uo, except tnose of the Irish Tree State j a cony of the Deport of the Committee is annexed for convenience of i eference. Since that time .His majesty’s Government in the United Kingdom have included provisions based on the recommend ations of the Deport in all their draft Commercial Treaties; I. te Water, Esq. recent/A .1 -A r 2 . recent examples may Tse found in the Commercial Treaty with Siam, signed on the 23rd November, 1937 (Treaty Series Ho.33 (1938) - Cmd. 5731) and the Commercial Treaty with the French and Tangier Zones of Morocco signed on the 18th July last (Cmd. 5823). As nothing occurred during the Imperial Conference of 1937 to suggest that the recommendations of 1930 should be departed from, His Majesty's Government in the United Kingdom have felt bound, in the absence of an indication that a change is desired by all the Governments concerned, to adhere to the practice recommended in 1930. I should add, as regards the proposed Treaty with Muscat, that, as the terms of the draft have now been agreed with the Sultan of Muscat, and as the conclusion of a new Treaty is urgently required in replacement of the existing Treaty which is shortly due to expire, we feel that it would be impracticable to suspend the final conclusion of the proposed Treaty pending consultation between the Governments concerned; we should not, of course, wish to suggest that this would preclude such consultation as to the inclusion of provisions of this character in future Commercial Treaties. The provisions of the draft Treaty with Muscat relating to extra-territorial jurisdiction (i.e. Articles 13, 14 and 15) stand on a somewhat different footing. In the first place, however, it may be pointed out that the provisions of the new Treaty do not involve any change in this respect, but are designed substantially to maintain existing rights. Moreover, in the case of a small country like Muscat where the native courts are extremely primitive and the local laws unsuitable in many respects for application to persons of Nuropean origin and where there is no institution such as the Mixed Courts in Hgypt as an alternative, the right of recourse to a Court maintained by the United Kingdom and the application of the law of British India rather/0® 'N 5. rather than local law must ? it is thought 5 he considered as indisputable a benefit, as are any of the other rights proposed to he obtained for British subjects generally under other provisions of the Treaty. The discussions which took place at the time of the Imperial Conference, 1937, and subsequently, regarding the application of extra-territorial jurisdiction, were understood by His Majesty’s Government in the United Kingdom to be related to the exercise of jurisdiction when obtained by treaty and not to the question of treaty provisions. They would consequently be more relevant to the later stage, namely, the issue of Orders in Council for the exercise of rights secured by treaty. The United Kingdom Government do not wish to dissent from the view that in general the exercise of extra-territorial jurisdiction in foreign countries in respect of British subjects belonging to the Union of South Africa must be regarded as exercised with the consent of His Majesty’s Government in the Union; they would be quite willing, if the Union Government should so desire, that the Order in Council which will eventually require to be passed for the exercise of such jurisdiction should be expressed to be passed at the request and with the consent of the Union Govern ment, or, alternatively, if that course were preferred, that the Union authorities should themselves make the necessary arrange ments for passing the Order required in respect of British subjects belonging to the Union. We feel, however, that the Union Government may well consider that Muscat, by reason of its special position, can properly be treated as standing in a different position from other foreign countries where extra territorial jurisdiction is or has been until recently enjoyed, such as China, Bgypt and Morocco. Legally and technically, Muscat is an independent State and His Majesty's Government in the United Kingdom do not exercise jurisdiction there over foreigners/mmforeigners in general. In practice ? however ? owing to the influence exercised there through the Government of India and the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf; Muscat stands in a special position which has considerable resemblance to that of a British protected State. In the case of British protected states - as for example the Persian Gulf Sheikhdoms of Koweit and Bahrein - it is assumed that His Majesty’s Government in the Union would not think of questioning the right of His Majesty’s Government in the United Kingdom to exercise juris diction over the rights of persons belonging to the Union as over other classes of British subjects? and other non-natives such as United States citizens or French nationals. Having regard to the special position of Muscat? it is thought that the Union Government may feel it preferable to adopt a similar attitude to the exercise of extra-territorial jurisdiction in Muscat and not to regard it as necessary to indicate by one or other of the means outlined above that authority in the territory concerned over British subjects belonging to the Union is exercised on the advice of His Majesty’s Government in fhe Union. An early expression of the views of the Union Government on the question of the Order in Council for the continued exercise of extra-territorial jurisdiction of Muscat would be appreciated? as we should like to proceed as soon as possible with the drafting of the necessary Order. The necessity for bringing the new Treaty into force next February and the time required for the various legal formalities would make it very desirable to put this in hand at the latest by the middle of December, and, if we have not heard further from the Union Crovernment by then? we trust that we may assume that they concur in a draft being prepared on the basis suggested above. Yours sincerely, Sd. Devonshire.f P.Z.7066/38. T.57^39 DOMINIONS OFFICE, S.W.l. 14th October, 1938. Dear Scallan, The Secretary of State’s letter of today’s date replies to the High Commissioner's letter of the 16th August on the subject of the draft Commercial Treaty with Muscat. There are two points not dealt with in the K. Scallan, Secretary of State's letter which I have been asked to mention to you informally. You will see that in paragraph 5 of the Secretary of State’s letter he refers to the question of consultation with the other Governments of^the British Commonwealth concerned. We have not included in the letter any suggestion as to the mode of consultation as we assume that, ii the Union Government wish to pursue the matter, they might prefer to undertake such consultation themselves. We should, of course, be quite willing to do so if the Union Government desired. In paragraph 5 of the Secretary of State's letter, the question of consultation as to the use of the provisions in question in future Commercial Treaties is also mentioned, I ought to say that there are several ' other Commercial Treaties now in contemplation, the drafts of which include provisions of the kind in question, e.g. with Chile, and Colombia, negotiations for which have already begun, as the Union Government have been informed. I have been asked to say that, while we do not wish to prejudice the general question, we feel that it might be rather embarrassing for us if the suggestion were made Esq# that/. - 2 . that we should suspend action on such treaties, ending consultation with the other Governments. We hope very much therefore that this point will not he raised. Y ours since rely ? (Sgd.) J.E. Dated 18th November,1938. No. P.Z.7662/38. Reference my telegram of the 17th November, No. 1979. Muscat Treaty. I enclose coTjy of the Arabic text which it is proposed, subject to your views and with the Sultan’s concurrence^, to adopt in preparation of signature copies. It embodies certain corrections in t he tex t which has already boen agreed upon with the Sultan (including revised text of Articles 12 and 19 enclosed with your express letter of the 4th November, No. 555-8). These corrections, which are understood to be self-explanatory, are considered essential for grammatical or other reasons. If you see no objection please consult Sultan and telegraph His Highness’s views. 2. You will observe that translator has inserted in Arabic your name and designation in the preamble and your name in the signature clause. If any corrections are required here please indicate them. 3. Certain minor changes have also been made in the English text which however will presumably not require to be mentioned to the Sultan. Apart from improvements in punctuation these arc - (a) In Article l(ii), lines 2 and 8, omit ”the term”. Repetition of these words is avoided in sub-sections (i)(iii) and (iv) of the Article. (W/2. (Id) In Article 13(3), line 2, substitute ‘’nor' for tl or u , (c) The following corrections are required in the list of amendments enclosed with your letter to the Sultan of the 8th July:- (i) Article 2(l), 19th line. The amendment should he - Before 11 shall*' insert 11 they'. (ii) Article 11. The phrase to he substituted should he 'v/hosenational he may he'. (iii) Article 13(1). The amendment should read 'subject to any right of appeal which Kis Majesty may provide'. This correction involves a change in the Arabic text also, which has been made in the enclosed copy. A corrected copy of the English text is enclosed. 4. You will note that in English text your signature will precede that of Sultan. This is due to fact that treaty will he printed for signature in a form which v/ill not permit space for the signatures side by side. This also applies to signature copies in Arabic. There would bo no objection in principle to Sultan's signature preceding yours in the Arabic copies, but this would involve reversal of order of names in the preamble and the signature clause of the Arabic text. This could no doubt be arranged, if you think it desirable, but as Arabic translation accepted by Sultan follows English text he will presumably not object to order of signatures also following that of the English copies. The issue of the above has been duly authorised. iSWd.l J. (v) The term 'foreign country' shall mean in relation to His Majesty any country or territory not under the sovereignty, protection, suzerainty or mandate of His Majesty, and, in relation to the Sultan, any country or territory not being a part of the territories of the Sultan.(1) There shall he perfect freedom of commerce and navigation between the territories of the High Contracting Parties Hach High Contracting Party shall allow the nationals of the other to enter all worts 3 creeks and rivers with their vessels and cargoes ? also to travel, reside and pursue commex' , ce and trade, whether wholesale or retail, in his territories provided, as regards nationals of the Sultan, that they satisfy and observe the conditions and regulations applicable in the territory of His Majesty in question to the entry, travel residence ana departure of all foreigners, and proviaed tnat nationals of His Majesty satisfy and observe the conditions applic able in the territories of the Sultan in regard to the entry of foreigners and that, in proceeding from the place where they reside in the territories of the Sultan to another place in his territories where for eign subjects do not already reside they shall, before doing so, notify in writing the local Omani authorities of the place where they reside, and such authorities shall inform them whether the intended destination is suitable for them to travel to or not; if the authorities in question notify the said nationals in writing that the intended destination is unsuitable, and if the said nationals persist in travelling to their destination, or if they should fail to notify the local authorities of their intended movements, they will proceed/I ' % r proceed at their own rislc. Farther subject to the provisions of Article 9, each Hiph Contracting Party shall allow in his territories the nationals of the other, whether personally or bp agent, freely to bargain for, buy, barter and sell goous, articles of import^, or local, production, whether intended for local sale, use or consumption, or for export, (2) Should the Sultan wish to establish any monopoly in any part of his territory such monopoly will be arranged in such away that it will not be detrimental to the trade in which nationals of His Majesty are at the time occupied in that part of his territory.enjoy throughout the territories of the Sultan v/ith respect to commerce, shipping ana the exercise of trade all the rights, privileges, immunities, aavantages and protection, of whatsoever nature, enjoyed by the nationals of the Sultan or the nationals of any other foreign country. ( Z) They shall not be liable to taxes, duties, imposts, restrictions or obligations of any description whatever, other or more onerous than those to which the nationals of the Sultan or the nationals of any other foreign country are subjected. (3) In all that relates to navigation and the treatment of shipping, the * Sultan undertakes to t reat British vessels not less favourably in any respect than Omani vessels or the vessels of any other foreign country. (3) The import duties leviable in the territories of the sultan on goods produced or manufactured in the territories of His Majesty and on goods imported by nationals of His Majesty shall be paid at the port or other place in the Sultan’s territories where the goods are first imported, and on payment thereof such goods shall thereafter be exempt within the said territories from all other Customs duties. (4) Customs duties shall not be levied in the territories of the Sultan on goods produced or manufactured in the territories of His Majesty or imported by nationals of His Majesty in the following cases, namely:-Article 5 (continued). (a) On goons which, being destined and manifested for a foreign country, are transhipped from one vessel or aircraft to another in any of the ports or airports of the Sultan or which have been for this purpose provisional ly landed and deposited in any of the Sultan's custom houses to await the arrival of a vessel or aircraft in which to be reshipped abroad; but goods so landed shall only be exempted if the consignee or his agent shall have, on the arrival of the vessel or aircraft, handed over the said goods to be kept unaer customs seal, and declared them as landed for transhipment designating at the same time the foreign place of destination, and if within a period not exceeding three months after their first landing the said goons are actually shipped for the said foreign country as originally declared and without having in the interval changed owners, and if all customs charges are paid before they are reshipped. Of these, the copy for retention by the Sultan has been prepared with the English text following the Arabic; (b) spare copies of the draft Treaty; (c) the instrument conveying the full powers issued by His Majesty authorising you to sign the Treaty for Great Britain and Northern Ireland and for India; and (d) a personal seal for your use in signing the Treaty. 2* Approval by His Majesty's Government and the Government of India of the signature of the Treaty is dependent on the completion of the following procedure, to which the Sultan has already agreed: (i) An exchange of letters with the Sultan with reference to Article 7, in the terms indicated in your letter to the Sultan of the 5th July, No. C/425; and (ii) Acceptance by the Sultan of a confidential letter, in terms already agreed to by His Highness, placing on record the procedure agreed on for the operation of Article 15. The letter that refers to Article 15 is confidential and will not he published. The question whether the other letters will he published is* under consideration. The Treaty was signed on the 5th February and it is intended to ratify it on the 11th February. 2. he do not thinh it will he possible to make our new Unseat Order-in-Council until about next Kay. The practical reasons rendering it impossible to get this Order out simultaneously with the ratification of the Treaty arc being •*-. explained to the Sultan, who is being asked to agree that our ' coupt in Huscat mhy operate under the old Order for two or three menths bonger. 1ne draft Order-in-Council is being prepared and will have to be sent to the Government of India and the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf. At the same time a copy will oe sent to the Dominions Office for communication to the Union High Commissioner, with an intimation that we do not t ink that any changes that may be made in it as a result of the observations of the Government of India or the Political Resident will be such as to be very material from the point of /tew of the Union Government. As soon as the final draft of the Order-in-Council is ready, we will communicate a copy to the Union Government. It will probably only be possible J.E. Stephenson Esc. , CVO. , OBE. / t0// Dominions Office.to do this ah out the same time as the Or del’ is submitted to the Privy Council and therefore it will he too late to make any alterations then. 4. As regards the High Commissioner’s letter of the loth December 3 it appears that the Union Government agree with the Dominions Office letter of the 14th October except for that part where it was suggested that i.Iuscat might be regarded as standing in a position similar to that of a British protected State. They raise no further objections to the provisions of the Treaty, including the provisions about extraterritorial jurisdiction, nor do they dissent from the view that the discussions at the Imperial Conference of 1937 only related to the exercise of jurisdiction obtained by Treaty and not to tne conclusion of treaties providing for such jurisdiction. Further they admit by implication that in the case of British protected states, including those in the Persian Gulf, we do not have to consult them as regards the terms of our Orders- in-Council or obtain their consent to exercise jurisdiction over Union nationals. They take the view, however, that Muscat stands on a different footing and we admitted that technically it did. Of the two alternative methods of showing that extraterritorial jurisdiction over Union nationals in Muscat would be exercised with the consent of His Majesty’s Government in the Union, which were set out in the Dominions Office letter, they adopt the second and submit a draft proclamation. 5. As regards the draft proclamation, we have the following immediate observations to make, while reserving the right to suggest other minor amendments when our own Order is drafted. 6. In Articles. 2, 3 and 4 the Union Government have inserted in their proclamation matters which in our case would not be dealt with in the Order-in—Council at all because the Tr do notaffect the action of our court. These matters would simply he left on the basis oi 1 the treaty ? and we would suggest that it would he more appropriate and correct that the Union proclamation; the object of which is to sanction the exercise of jurisdiction by our courts over Union nationals? should only deal with matters which actually affect the consular court and that therefore Articles 2? 3 and 4 should be omitted. 7. Article 2 deals with the position in the Sultan's court where we have a treaty right? the substance of which is reproduced in rhis Article. he should claim the observance of this treaty right? but we can?iot enforce it or add to its validity in any way by issuing legislative provisions of our own. S. Similarly? Article :3 deals with the action of the Sultan of Muscat's police and substantially the same comment applies. 9. Article 4 deals with what was an undertaking by both .parties to the Treaty as to the manner in which they will exercise their jurisdiction. It is hardly a provision which can be enacted legislatively in this way and we should not put it in our Order-in-Council. 10. Similar reasoning suggests that in the preamble of the dralt proclamation? the words ''and certain further privileges have also been accorded 1 ' at the end of paragraph 1 should be omitted and that the beginning of paragraph 3 of the* preamble should read 'And whereas it is desirable that Union nationals should be rendered subject to the jurisdiction etc.' 11. In paragraph 2 of the preamble? the penultimate line would? we think? read better if it said ; ‘. . . representatives? over all His Majesty's subjects within the territories of His Highness.' Yours sincerely? 3d. H. Dunbar.P.Z.8438/30 Enclosure in Dominions Office covering note dated 27th December, 1938. Muscat Treaty.India Office, Whitehall, London• S.1. 1435/40• 13th March, 1940* Sir, 1 am directed by the Secretary of State to forward dated 9th March ) a copy of a letter from the Foreign Office with enclo sure. ) regarding the application to certain specified territories of the Treaty dated 5th February, 1939, between the United Kingdom and India and Muscat, and to request that a communication may be addressed to His Highness the Sultan in the terms indicated by the Foreign Office in accordance with the provisions of Art.19 of the Treaty. The Hon’ble It.Col.C.G.Prior, CIS.P.Z. 1435/40. location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: 'File 8/65 IV MUSCAT STATE AFFAIRS: RENEWAL OF COMMERCIAL TREATY.'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the front to the rear of the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 246; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 100-241; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled. A previous foliation sequence, which is also circled, has been superseded and therefore crossed out.

mods.abstract: This file relates to the renewal of the 1891 Commercial Treaty between Britain and Muscat. The original treaty was given a term of twelve years, which was extended at regular intervals afterwards, initially for several years at a time and later on an annual basis.The file concerns the replacement of the existing treaty with a new treaty, following a request from the Sultan of Muscat and Oman [Sa‘īd bin Taymūr Āl Bū Sa‘īd] that the two parties enter into negotiations to revise the existing treaty. Matters covered include the following: informal discussions with the Sultan regarding the revision of the existing treaty; the Sultan's reported unwillingness to agree to any further renewals of the treaty in its existing form after 11 February 1938; amendments to the initial draft of the new revised treaty, and the preparation of signature copies, in English and Arabic; the signing and ratifying of the new treaty, on 5 and 7 February 1939 respectively; the extension of the provisions of the treaty to certain British territories.The file features the following principal correspondents: the Political Agent and Consul at Muscat; the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf; the Secretary of State for India; the Sultan of Muscat and Oman; officials of the India Office, the Foreign Office, the Dominions Office, the Colonial Office, and the Government of India.In addition to correspondence, the file includes the following: copies of the initial draft of the revised treaty, in English and Arabic (ff 18-53 and ff 54-70 respectively); a signature copy of the draft treaty, in Arabic (ff 100-111); copies of the draft certificate of exchange of ratifications, in English and Arabic (f 177 and ff 179-180).The file's Arabic material consists of the aforementioned copies of the treaty, several items of correspondence, and a transcript of a speech given by the Political Resident on the occasion of the signing of the treaty (English translations are included).
